text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with Chicken Little that's right
we're gonna take a very small chicken
and make it even smaller to create a
show-stopping presentation using a
boning technique that's gonna seem
impossible but it's not I mean it is a
little difficult but not impossible and
unfortunately people get those two
things confused all the time but anyway
with the help of this video I'm pretty
sure you're gonna be able to master this
so with that let's go ahead and get
started and the first thing you're gonna
have to do is find one of these a very
small chicken which are generally sold
under the name game hen and the one
you're going to want to find is the one
and a half pound variety which is the
perfect size for this technique and the
first thing we'll want to do is remove
the wings right where they attach to the
body ideally using one of these nice
sharp relatively thin boning knives and
since cutting through bone is pretty
hard we always want to find that nice
spot in the middle of the joint where
the cartilage of the ball attaches to
the cartilage of the socket which I find
much easier to locate with the chicken
upside down so we'll go ahead and remove
both wings and of course save those for
stock or to eat and then what we want to
do next is make a cut on either side of
the breastbone which is pretty easy to
feel and we'll simply cut down on either
side of that right down to the rib cage
and once we've cut down far enough to
see and feel what's going on we're
simply gonna trim that breast away from
the carcass keeping our knife nice and
flat against the ribcage and when we get
towards the front we'll sort of cut
against that wishbone and as long as the
knife is angled against the bone and not
the meat you should be okay and as I
said we'll cut that breast away from the
carcass and then in the back we'll do
the same thing cutting the meat away
from the pelvic bone and again just let
your tip of the knife feel where that
bone is and stay against that and then
we'll go ahead and finish cutting
through the skin on the front of the
bird at which point we will grab that
leg and dislocate the hip joint and then
to finish our cut we'll press against
the carcass with our knife hand while
pulling the leg away with the other and
that's going to allow us to trim that
off retaining the maximum amount of meat
and skin sure might look a little bit
ragged but
that's only because of the mistakes we
shouldn't bother you because they don't
bother me
because I know once this is cooked it
won't matter and yes I did this to both
sides and actually showed you the one
that came out the worst you know to
build your confidence but anyway let's
not celebrate yet
because we still have to remove that
thigh bone was just like the breast bone
we will feel for with our finger and
then cut on either side and once you get
it started it's pretty easy to get your
fingers underneath and once we're able
to grab that it is pretty easy to trim
out all right so first we'll liberate
that end and then we will trim down
until we find that joint and cut right
through there at its weakest point which
will be where it attaches and then once
that bone has been successfully removed
it's time for probably the trickiest
part of this operation we want to trim
down through the meat and the tendons
about an inch away from that joint being
careful that we're not cutting through
any skin okay so just go around sort of
pulling that meat away from the joint
towards the foot and by the way it
doesn't hurt every once in a while to
sort of stop and kind of pull that leg
out like this just to sort of reorient
ourselves and to make sure we're not
cutting through any skin and then once
we've gone around like that and we can
get a good look at that joint we are
ready to cut off most of it and for that
we're probably going to want to use a
bigger knife so we'll take one more look
to make sure there's no skin in the way
and that's pulled well back and then
we'll take a big knife and cut through
right where the cartilage meets the bone
okay don't go down the bone just right
there where you see the cartilage
attached to the bone and we'll make one
clean cut right through there and that's
it we've now created basically a pocket
in which we're gonna stuff our breast
which is gonna give our chicken little
its signature shape but we'll get to
that right now we have one more move to
do and that would be if we want to cut
the foot joint off and I do it because I
think it looks better once these are
roasted so we'll cut those off again
right where the cartilage meets the bone
and then once that's been accomplished
these are ready to spread with our
compound butter which I'm going to show
you how to make now so into our mortar
we're gonna put some sliced garlic as
well as some kosher salts
some freshly ground black pepper and
about a teaspoon of freshly picked herbs
I'm using thyme and rosemary and then
last but not least a little bit of
butter and then once all that's in there
we'll go ahead and bash mash and smash
this until it's relatively smooth and
yes this is easier to do if you smash
everything before you add your butter
but for this small of an amount it
really doesn't matter that much and by
the way this is my compound butter which
is not necessarily the same thing as
your compound butter so feel free to
tweak this any way you want you are
after all the bobby flay of your petit
Poulet so go ahead and get creative if
you want and then what we'll do once our
butter is ready and we've generously
season the inside of our chicken with
salt and pepper spread that on the
inside at which point we will shape our
chicken littles so we'll go ahead and
apply about two to three teaspoons of
our butter as shown at which point we're
going to take the breast section and
sort of snuggle that up into that pocket
we made in the thigh and theoretically
we should have just enough skin to cover
everything an ideally while doing this
at leg bone is centered and sticking
straight up and by the way do not think
too much while you're doing this all
right your fingers are gonna know what
to do so don't distract them just let it
happen and if everything goes according
to plan you should end up with something
that looks like this and I should also
mention just get it close because we're
actually going to hold this in shape
with some foil which is the next step so
what we'll do is tear off some foil as
long as it is wide which should give you
a square and then we'll fold that in
half and then fold that top edge over
about an inch
that will go ahead and grease this up
with a little bit of olive oil or more
butter if you want and once we have our
foil properly lubricated we'll go ahead
and take our chicken little and place it
directly in the center and then we'll
grab either end kind of trapping it in
the middle and ideally that foil is
coming up a couple inches okay high
enough to keep it in shape but not so
high that it covers the skin and
prevents it from getting brown and then
all we need to do is sort of pinch it
together and then fold one side one way
and one side the other and then we can
just fine-tune it until we think it's
perfect or at least reasonably close
okay so nothing really too complicated
especially if you compare it to the
other steps so I went ahead and did that
to both my portions and then transfer
those on dual plates because I do like
to prep these ahead and then cover them
in plastic and pop them in the fridge
until I'm ready to roast okay for one
thing after all that we need to rest but
also I think these come out better if
they go in the oven cold because that
way our skin has a little more time to
brown before the inside reaches our
desired internal temp so I did pop mine
in the fridge for a few hours at which
point I took him out and transferred
them into this pan for roasting but
before we put those in the oven we will
brush them with a little bit of olive
oil or again melted butter that depends
on how French you want these and then we
should probably also season the outsides
with some salt and then once those have
been shined up and seasoned they're
ready to place into the center of a very
hot 450 degree oven for about 30 minutes
or so or until they reach an internal
temp of 150 but what I think we should
do after about 20 minutes is pull them
out and remove the foil and then put
them back in to finish and of course it
goes without saying that we're
definitely going to pour any and all
accumulated juices back in the pan that
would be considered mandatory although I
should mention this entire step is
actually optional you could just cook
them all the way in the foil but I do
think would that remove they do brown up
a little bit better so we will probably
remove those from the foil and then
we'll go ahead and pop those back in for
another ten minutes or so or until they
look like this and as I said have an
internal temperature of 150 and if that
sounds low it's not
and I'll talk about that on the blog and
then what we could do is just serve
these but what I think we should do is
place our heat on medium and ladle in a
little bit of stock or wine or water or
some kind of liquid and that way while
we're plating these up we could to glaze
this pan and use some of those drippings
over the top so that's what I'm gonna do
and so should you
so while my pan de glaze I went ahead
and serve this up on some mirepoix
braised farro which I think we did a
video for and then like I said I'm going
to spoon some of those deglaze pan
drippings over the top and then since I
had the time I garnish with a few sprigs
of that and that's it my chicken little
is ready to serve and as far as
spectacular show-stopping presentations
go it does not get much more impressive
than this okay this looks so good your
guests are actually gonna forget you had
the nerve to serve chicken at a fancy
dinner party and above and beyond its
awe-inspiring visual appeal because we
roasted that breast surrounded by that
fatty or juicier thigh and skin this
meat comes out so tender and so
succulent
it really is a fantastic technique and
besides these smaller younger chickens
are just naturally juicy anyway so I
just really love how this comes out and
so will you if you push yourself to try
this technique and I know it seems
daunting but as you saw we can make
these ahead and then take a nap and then
roast them and serve them later plus if
you make like four or six or eight of
these you're really going to get that
boning and shaping technique down which
will of course significantly raise your
kitchen game and who does not want their
kitchen game raised but anyway that's it
what I'm calling Chicken Little whether
you make this for a group on a holiday
or just a certain someone on day night
when you're trying to get lots of
compliments I really do hope you give
this a try soon so head over to food
wishes calm for all the ingredient
amounts and more info as usual and as
are we
enjoy
